content.question: Substance Appearance Boiling Point Density Water Clear, colorless liquid <math alttext="100.0 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1.00 gram per milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g/mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> White, crystalline solid <math alttext="1935.5 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1935.5</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="2.15 grams per milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.15</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g/mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Mixture of water <math alttext="Plus X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Clear, colorless liquid <math alttext="101.6 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>101.6</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1.08 grams per milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.08</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g/mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> The table above summarizes data given to a student to evaluate the type of change that took place when substance <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was mixed with water. The student claimed that the data did not provide enough evidence to determine whether a chemical or physical change took place and that additional tests were needed. Which of the following identifies the best way to gather evidence to support the type of change that occurred when water and <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> were mixed?

choices.label: Measuring the melting point of the mixture of water and <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
Adding another substance to the mixture of water and <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to see whether a solid forms

Measuring and comparing the masses of the water, <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the mixture of water and <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Measuring the electrical conductivities of <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the mixture of water and <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: Measuring the electrical conductivities of <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the mixture of water and <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 6.B: Support a claim with evidence from experimental data.
